docs.title: Kicad Snippets
docs.text: During my years of tinkering and circuit design, I found myself repeatedly redoing the same schematics over and over again. Thus this repository serves as my collection of commonly used circuitry that I would refer to when i have to use them again.

docs.title: Basics
docs.text: Depending on the purpose of the circuit board, there will be many different design choice and rules that one will have to follow.

docs.title: Inputs and Outputs (IOs)
docs.text: These are components that will serve as a connection between a board and another board, or a board with another physical entity

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.
  • mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server.
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.

docs.title: Considerations
docs.text:
Some considerations to take when choosing the right connector for your IO

  • number of pins
  • power (current & voltage) rating for EACH pin
  • form factor
  • gender
  • purpose
  • the user

So, if the intended purpose of a output port is for USB (for example), we should use a USB Connector as it is obvious (hopefully) to the user what set of wires can be used to connect to the port and in what manner (UI/UX consideration). Granted, there will be exceptions to this too (more later).

docs.title: Universal Serial Device
docs.text: The USB port is one of the most common IO port found on electronic devices (but not all).

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
The USB port is provides 2 devices to exchange:

  • Power
  • Data (Serial, Differential Pair)

* note: USB cables can be the limiting factor where they might not have the same internal wires to support the maximum capability the port can provide. (ie. USB power only wires)

docs.title: Types of USB
docs.text:
There are quite a number of different USB ports.

  • USB A
  • USB B
  • USB Mini
  • USB Micro
  • USB C

Personal opinion: for the love of god, please use the latest: USB C. It is not that hard to work with + its not THAT much more expensive.

docs.title: USB Standards
docs.text:
I will only focus on the slower (and older) standards as it is the only ones that matter in this juncture. Some embedded devices (microcontroller/microprocessors) have an on-board USB "driver" that allows direct hookup from the chip to the port (without an external IC) to communicate with another device via USB.

Standard AKA USB 1.1 USB Full-Speed (FS) USB 2.0 USB High-Speed (HS)

For more information on USB connectivity types and standards, you can refer to Tripp Lite's USB Connectivity Types & Standards.

docs.title: Disclaimer
docs.text:
Do note that there is a difference between the USB port and the USB standard.
